description.narrative: KAIPTC is an official regional center for peacekeeping missions to ECOWAS. It is West Africa's Institute for Conflict Prevention and Peace and Security Studies at the operational level. The center holds courses for military, civilian and police personnel involved in peacekeeping missions across the world, and conducts research on the causes and subsequent management of conflicts

KAIPTC är ett officiellt regionalt center för fredsbevarande insatser åt ECOWAS. Det är Västafrikas institut för konfliktförebyggande och freds- och säkerhetsstudier på operativ nivå. Centret håller kurser för militär, civil och polisiär personal som deltar i fredsfrämjande insatser över hela världen, och forskar om orsaker och efterföljande hantering av konflikter

KAIPTC:s mission for the strategy period of 2014-2018 is:"KAIPTC provides globally-recognised capacity for international actors on African peace and security through training, education and research to foster peace and stability in Africa"The four objectives for the same period are:1. To enhance the capacity of ECOWAS, AU, UN and other relevant actors in multi-dimensional peacekeeping and peace-building (integrated peace support operations) through training2. To deepen understanding of and discourses on critical peace and security issues in Africa through research and policy engagements3. To contribute to knowledge creation that informs best practice in conflict prevention, management and resolution in Africa4. To ensure an efficient, effective and responsive governance and management system in the Centre

description.narrative: The Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Centre (KAIPTC) works to foster peace and stability in Africa by providing capacity for international and national actors on African peace and security through training, education and research for military, police, and civilian personnel for multidimensional peacekeeping and peace support operation in the ECOWAS region, Africa and beyond. Overall, the program is believed to have contributed positively to human security. However, due to KAIPTC’s work largely being process-oriented, it is difficult to firmly attribute change to specific interventions. Nonetheless, some examples of contribution impact can be identified and summarized as follows: Regarding strategic objective 1: To enhance the capacity of ECOWAS, AU, UN and other relevant actors in multi-dimensional peacekeeping and peace-building (integrated peace support operations) through training - Trained a total of 10,238 (average of 23% women) people in areas of peace support operations, conflict prevention and management, election observation, protection of civilians, maritime security and transnational organised crime, violent extremism and terrorism, the Responsibility to Protect and more, - Received two certificates of UN training recognition for their courses on protection of civilians in armed conflicts and police pre-deployment (PPDT). The latter authorizes KAIPTC to directly submit participating officers in its PPDT courses to the UN police division at the Department of peacekeeping to peacekeeping operation, thereby KAIPTC gains a more direct connection to peace and security on the continent, - Trained 403 female domestic election observers and 24 women in special election observation and election dispute resolution, the latter resulting in participants being included in the AU Commission’s Special Envoy on Women, Peace and Security’s pool of high-ranking African women to be recommended for leadership roles in observation missions or key roles in election dispute resolution efforts, - Trained 91 police personnel in support of the UN/AU Mission in Darfur and the AU Mission in Somalia on human rights; women, peace and security; child protection and sexual exploitation, humanitarian assistance, mediation etc, - Trained 1368 people responsible for disaster preparedness and management in 14 West African countries as well as a selection of ECOWAS Commission officials, - Trained 450 people across 15 counties in Liberia on disaster preparedness and management, - Supported ECOWAS’ Standby Force through contributing to the validation of its civilian dimension policy framework, providing training for ECOWAS officials on human rights, as well as delivering a course on civilian peacekeepers to ECOWAS as well as ECCAS, EASF and SADC, Regarding Strategic Objective 2: To deepen understanding of and discourses on critical peace and security issues in Africa through research and policy engagements - Produced a section on Ghana, Togo and Côte d’Ivoire for a joint study with ECOWAS and their three Training Centres of Excellence (TCE) on causes, responses and resolutions of emerging violent clashes between farmers and nomadic herdsmen in the region, - Conducted a mapping study on sources of conflict and resilience within the Mano River Union and Sahel zones which created the basis for a conference held together with the ECOWAS mediation unit and the Gambian government on infrastructure for peace in ECOWAS member states, - Contributed to the development of the ECOWAS Standby Force Conduct and Discipline Policy Framework with a focus on the whistle-blower policy for ECOWAS peace support operations, - Completed a small arms baseline survey to guide the development of an arms database, provided training to governance and security sector institutions and produced 2 training manuals for senior police officers and county security council members as part of its project to strengthen policing and arms control capacities of the Liberian government to meet operational challenges post UNMIL Drawdown in Liberia, - Supported the revision of Liberia’s and Ghana’s national security strategies, - Provided technical assistance to the AU’s work on Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (DDR) with an AU DDR training manual for standardizing DDR Training within the AU security infrastructure, - Provided technical support to the South Sudan National Women’s Peace Dialogue with a plan for monitoring the implementation of the agreement on the resolution of the conflict in South Sudan, - Launched its journal on African Peace and Security which includes critical analyses of knowledge and practice on conflict prevention, peace-making, peacekeeping and peacebuilding with respect to the African experience, - Increased its thinktank rating. In 2014, KAIPTC ranked 51st among top 65 global foreign policy and international affairs thinktanks and is the highest ranking organisation from sub-Saharan Africa within the category. Regarding Strategic Objective 3: To contribute to knowledge creation that informs best practice in conflict prevention, management and resolution in Africa - Graduated 433 Masters students and two PhD students, - Signed a Memorandum of Cooperation with Charles University in the Czech Republic to support an exchange of academic staff, students and knowledge, - Held annual Kofi Annan-Dag Hammarskjöld lectures on a range of themes, including the future of peace and security in Africa, a West African perspective on the continuing challenges of peace and security in Africa, preventing armed conflicts: identifying and mitigating risks, etc. Regarding Strategic Objective 4: To ensure an efficient, effective and responsive governance and management system in the Centres - Launched a gender policy which mainstreams and integrates gender into all aspects of its work and organisation, - adopted a gender sensitive and sexual harassment policy with workshops to sensitize staff on the issues, - Established a nursing and childcare facility on the KAIPTC premises, Revised, introduced, and implemented a range of important internal policies, - Improved its monitoring and evaluation (M&E) systems, including assessing ways to strengthen the system, developing a M&E manual and launching a web-based monitoring tool, - Developed its communication and marketing strategies and launched a redesigned website to increase its competitiveness with other similar organisations.
